pros: Terry Shaw is a respectable Chief Executive Officer.
cons: One cannot help but question the necessity of titles like "Executive Director of Sports Partnerships" and similar roles that seem more focused on grandiose nomenclature than on practical contributions to patient care. The bloated salaries attached to these positions further compound the issue. These non-clinical executives are earning at least three times the salary of a nurse, and yet their contributions to the actual delivery of healthcare services remain questionable at best. AdventHealth needs to remember that without the nurses, doctors, and other team members who work tirelessly to ensure the well-being of patients, their executives would not be enjoying these extravagant salaries. It is the nurses who provide comfort and care to patients, the doctors who diagnose and treat illnesses, and the dedicated team members who keep the healthcare system running smoothly. These individuals deserve to be recognized and rewarded appropriately for their invaluable contributions.

pros: Faith-based employer - can help create a better work environment depending on who you work for and location/department/rollup Almost-competitive pay for IT All-inclusive non-discrimination policy The Service Standards are great Opportunities for growth & to change positions Continued education benefits
cons: The push for growth is taking its toll on front-line employees. Many long-term employees have witnessed the change from what felt like a family-owned business to a corporate environment. Central Florida Division (CFD) IT employees are paid less than IT employees located on the corporate campus in Altamonte Springs - a suburb of Orlando. Despite promises of equal pay, there are still discrepancies for like jobs. IT contracts have been signed without IT vetting. Employee recognition, benefits, and perks vary greatly depending on where and what team you work for Clinicians are constantly being forced to take on more responsibilities which takes away from their attention to patient care Regional IT employees are often left out or overlooked by Corporate initiatives leading those employees to feel as though they don't belong to either the Region or Corporate (All IT employees are Corporate). This is most evident in the Central Florida Region. Corporate pulls in the CFR teams when it's convenient to them such as requiring onsite training or conferences. When it comes to perks related to such things as employee appreciation, they are left to Regional leadership for recognition. Corporate HR leadership fails to demonstrate the Service Standards at times. An example is the head of Corporate HR sent gift cards to Corporate employees for IT Employee Appreciation Day. The email was sent to some regional IT employees. The head of HR refused to acknowledge the mistake nor did she correct the issue; she left it to regional leaders to correct her mistake. When Corporate Leaders fail to set the right example, it sends ripples throughout the entire organization.

review_title: Managers Throw You Under The Bus
pros: Chief executives acknowledge the importance of caring for their employees.
cons: I feel compelled to share my disappointing experience working under a manager who consistently throws employees under the bus. It is disheartening to witness such unprofessional behavior and lack of leadership. I hope my review serves as a warning to potential job seekers considering this company. During my time with this organization, I had the unfortunate experience of encountering a manager who prioritized their own interests over the well-being of their team. Whenever a problem or mistake arose, instead of taking responsibility or providing guidance, this manager would swiftly shift blame onto their subordinates. They had a knack for deflecting any criticism or repercussions onto others, effectively leaving their employees to face the consequences alone. What bothered me most was the complete disregard for teamwork and collaboration. In a healthy work environment, a manager should foster an atmosphere of support and trust. However, this individual seemed to relish in exploiting their position of authority to protect their own reputation, even at the expense of their team members. Furthermore, this behavior created a toxic work environment where employees felt constant pressure to cover their tracks and avoid making any mistakes. The fear of being thrown under the bus created an atmosphere of mistrust and paranoia, inhibiting productivity and hindering professional growth. It is worth noting that this manager's actions did not go unnoticed by other colleagues. The negative impact on morale was palpable, with many talented individuals becoming demotivated and disengaged. As a result, the team's performance suffered, and several highly skilled employees left the company, seeking better working conditions elsewhere. I firmly believe that a company's success hinges on effective leadership and fostering a culture of accountability and support. Unfortunately, this manager failed on both fronts. Their unprofessional behavior hindered teamwork, eroded trust, and ultimately damaged the company's reputation. To potential job seekers considering this company, I urge you to thoroughly evaluate the work environment and the leadership before making a decision. Take heed of reviews like this, as they shed light on crucial aspects of the organization that may not be apparent during the hiring process. In conclusion, my experience working under a manager who throws employees under the bus was profoundly negative. The lack of accountability and teamwork created an unhealthy and unproductive work environment. I hope the company addresses these issues promptly to prevent further harm to their employees and overall success.

pros: Was a great place to work.
cons: It saddens me to have to write this, but our leaders are not listening. My team went remote three years ago with the pandemic. During that time, we were very short staffed, but we worked together, living our services standards and got the work done. We worked the extra hours being remote and didn’t have a problem with it—no commute, flexibility with work and home balance, but we still got the work done working those long hours and weekends. Productivity has increased dramatically with this flexibility. Even with all the extra work, I have never been happier in my career than with the remote lifestyle. The corporate team was told last year that we would stay remote and only need to come in once a month. Based on this promise, team members changed their lives—they moved, sold cars, made changes to their family dynamic, all while still managing to get the work done. Trust has been broken as we were lied to. We are now being told we must return to the office three days a week. If team members don’t trust their leaders what does that say about AdventHealth? We are being told that going back will increase collaboration. My team thrived working remote and collaborating through team meetings and chats. I have actually talked more with coworkers through teams than I ever did in the office. With the three-day mandate back to the office team members will leave. I will leave and know that at least half of my team (team of 25) is looking for a company that offers remote work. For those who stay they, will have the burden of the additional work because of fewer staff but the dedication and commitment to the job will be lost. Productivity will be lost as those hours we saved everyday will now be wasted driving. For the team members that stay I believe there will be increased mental health issues due to additional stress, expense of gas, tolls, car maintenance and family challenges.

review_title: Outstanding place to Work and Grow
job_title: HRIS Specialist in Altamonte Springs, FL
pros: AdventHealth is a Christ Centered organization that truly lives their values.  They are a rapidly expanding organization that provides healthcare services from cradle to grave.  Their goal is never discharge a patient, but rather manage their care throughout their life.  As an Employee, you can advance your career in a corporate setting or move up through one of our many healthcare facilities/outpatient clinics/physician practices or nursing homes.  You can also attend our University to grow your career.  Visit us at AdventHealth.com.
cons: The organization is huge (80K+ employees) and the environment is competitive - bring your "A" game.

pros: Decent pay at the corporate level and some mental health resources for employees.
cons:
Management was abusive and did not demonstrate the inspirational and inclusive leadership AdventHealth claims to exemplify. On multiple occasions individuals on our team witnessed an individual verbally threaten physical violence against us and other employees, as well as demonstrate abusive behavior. This was reported to HR after an investigation was opened, but many of the abusive behaviors continued and executive leadership either endorsed or ignored the behavior. 

This individual openly disparaged our director to us the second our director would leave a meeting, and spoke poorly of other directors and our executive leadership to us—oftentimes encouraging us to ignore their orders or insight because they didn’t know as much as they did. I assume this was in an attempt to isolate us from other teams. We were also told point blank that a long standing fellow employee on our team was blocked from a promotion due to personal extreme dislike for that employee—which is unprofessional on a number of levels. This individual also discussed their personal life at length with us, at one time going into explicit detail about their personal sexual life with their spouse.

During peaks of pandemic waves when our team was told by executive leadership that we were remote, we had mandatory meetings at an employee’s house for during work hours, where current workplace mask mandates were not enforced. 

On multiple occasions, our team attempted to provide feedback about work conditions, but each time it was met with an incredible amount of resistance, defensiveness, and anger from this individual. The feedback was then back onto to the team—as if we were responsible for abusive behavior. 

In addition to these issues, toxic workplace culture was encouraged on our team. During our transition from remote to hybrid, executive leadership was in agreement about the amount flexibility in our day, but apparently certain people saw it as an opportunity to exert control over their teams. We were verbally berated about our coming and goings and given an assigned seating chart. An individual then took it upon themselves to start tracking the entire department’s attendance—yet this behavior didn’t seem to be discouraged (which is strange considering this wasn’t that person’s role and seems to be a form of time theft). 

The behavior I witnessed is completely inexcusable for a member of leadership to exemplify. It’s extremely unfortunate AdventHealth leadership allows it and I worry for my past fellow employees who still have to endure this inexcusable behavior. For the safety and health of employees, I don’t believe certain individuals should have any direct reports. 

Overall company culture leaves much to be desired. AdventHealth is openly anti-union and discriminates against people who aren’t Adventist. They only allow seventh day adventists past a certain point into executive leadership and fast track young students from SDA universities into leadership positions. 

AdventHealth’s definitions of “remote” work is purposefully misleading and would actually be called hybrid. At the time of this review, they’re still asking “remote” employees to come in for meetings.

The healthcare isn’t even great for a healthcare company? They’re a multi-billionaire “non-profit” and can’t even give their employees $0 deductible healthcare.

Raises were not competitive—they didn’t match inflation and junior staff members received higher wages than senior ones.

review_title: If you believe performance should be recognized, AdventHealth may not be the right fit for you
pros: It’s a great place to work if you are an Adventist.
cons:
If you are a self-motivated, high-performing, hard-working employee, AdventHealth may not be the right culture for you.

There are no merit increases for staff. There are no performance-related bonus incentives for staff. Depending on your department’s leadership, even simple verbal recognition or appreciation can be sparse or non-existent. 

Healthcare benefits are expensive if you work at Corporate.

Combine that with organizational pressure to produce more with less FTEs, a deeply entrenched culture of favoritism and nepotism, and a decision-making process that starts with the decision and then looks for evidence to support what was already decided.

job_title: Consumer Experience Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: -Professional environment -Friendly employees -Good Benefits
cons: I have no cons about the company.

pros: Their insurance is Pretty cheap
cons:
If you’re not Adventist do not think about moving up, they bring Adventist kids for internships and they move up the ladder quicker than any other employee, it’s absolutely disgusting how much they favor them. Even during the pandemic only the Adventist kids got the tuition reimbursement, no other employee did. Everyone knows about these kids, but since they’re one of the two largest companies in Orlando, I guess no one bothers to do anything. 

They’re HR staff is rude and disrespectful. I transferred 3 times in my 4 years, always for a better position, and each time not only would the HR rep message me at 9-10 pm at night ONLY, but would try to hassle me on my pay. I’m thankful that I know my worth, and I fought it. But, this lady literally said that my surgical experience had nothing to do with my inpatient job?????? 

I moved to corporate after the pandemic thinking it would have been better, and it’s not. The managers have no interpersonal skills, they micromanage you, and they have the audacity to say that .36 dollar pay increase is fair. Some people got no pay increase at all because they were not “eligible”. 

They are SUPER disorganized. They had TWO years to prepare for the switch of EHR from Athena to Epic. And the week before they were still things up in the air, and managers not knowing what is gonna happen. Half my team was worried that they were going to lose their jobs because they didn’t know how to do it in Epic.

Lastly, they DO NOT care about their employees. I was there for 4.5 years, and I was excited when I first joined. AdventHealth had a good name in Orlando, but not only was I disappointed in the care I was forced to give to patients, but I was disappointed in how little they care about their employees. I had a manager demand that I come in to work THE DAY I found out my grandfather passed away. She literally told me to my face that she thought I was lying and that I needed to come into work. I had a few very awful experiences with certain employees calling me racist names, and I reported them to HR. NOTHING happened, they promised they’d help me find a new unit to move to, nope. They said that someone would contact me about filling a grievance, nope. 

I LOVED my job, the work I did as a data analyst was fun for me. My coworkers in my last role were amazing, I still keep in contact with them. But, I was so tired of being treated poorly and getting paid like crap that I just had to leave. The new job I have now DOUBLED my salary, that I how bad I was underpaid.

review_title: Think twice if you’re not Adventist
pros: The company is financially sound so no one pay was affected throughout Covid. They do a lot of employee surveys so it seems they care what the employees are feeling, although with an organization this size change takes a long time to be implemented. Jeans on fridays. Corporate office closes at 3pm on Friday’s to observe the Adventist sabbath so all work ends at 3.
cons: Office is incredibly conservative. Ties were mandatory up until 2018. If you are not religious or Adventist, the culture can be very suppressing at times. Devotions before every meeting, bible verses everywhere, religious statues all over corporate campus etc. I am not sure that everyone is aware of how extremely religious it is- they view themselves as an extension of the church so you always feel like you’re working in a church which makes you feel like you always have to have a filter on. If you’re Adventist I would imagine it would be the perfect place but if you are not religious, be aware of this before working here. Holidays, sick days and vacation are all one “bank”. You would think working for a healthcare system that the insurance would be good but it’s nothing amazing.

pros: Both clinical and non-clinical staff are genuinely interested in patient outcomes and satisfaction.  I constantly see staff members going out of their way to help.  The campus is very large and confusing to navigate but staff members will stop what they are doing to offer assistance.  I personally witnessed a worker pay for a family member's dinner when she had been sleeping at the hospital for over a week with a critically ill patient.  There are plenty of opportunities to volunteer for various healthcare related organizations as well.  It is especially nice to have Spiritual Ambassadors available to pray with patients, families or even staff.
cons: Salaries are not top-notch and staffing is often short, which risks patient safety.  Nurses are constantly at risk of being "called off", leaving team members short handed.  Management spends a lot of time, especially at new employee orientation, pointing out that there are plenty of others who would gladly take your position if you are not happy with their policies.

review_title: Overall a good company to work for.
pros: I like the company, the mission statement and that they are non-profit. The pay is competitive.
cons:
Senior management does not understand what it is like in the trenches.  We went to team nursing at the hospital where I  work.  10-12 patients for one RN, with a LPN as med tech, supposedly  a CNA for every 10-12 pts., supposedly  a virtual  nurse for admissions and discharges.  Sometimes we have one CNA  for 24+ pts., sometimes no CNA  at all. Sometimes no virtual  nurse.  Short staffed because  so many have quit. We have very ill patients with lots of problems, heparin drips, etc. 10-12 to juggle is not safe, especially with the amount of documenting we have to do. They ae trying to stop the mass exit and are making changes. Hopefully things will be better soon.
Pro/Con depending on smoking  status: they will not hire you if you smoke and they do test you.
FYI: You need to be physically fit. The work physical requires you to do squats, leg lifts and touching your toes to check for back problems.

pros: Supportive, like family, fair, honest, collaboration
cons: Flexibility, work load, floating, balance, advancement

review_title: Doesn't Know How to Get Things Done
pros: Initially, seems like great outfit.  But, they don't walk their talk.  They have big leadership meetings where it is all send.  There is no interaction and no problem to solution reviews.  Pretty junior management except top tier executives--good and bad; you can do well, but you also have tons of coaching and support required.  Lars, the head of the company, is terrific.
cons: Says they're into Healthy 100, but not introducing offerings.  Too many decisions makers.  No processes for new product development and implementation.  You make your 'budget' and nothing else really matters.  They don't do due dates.  Things take forever to get implemented if they ever do.  Their safety record is not good enough.  Pay is low at management levels.Very much a fix/cure it mentality.

review_title: Stable and relatively enjoyable place to work
job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Winter Park, FL
pros: If you have the opportunity to actually work in one of their hospitals the experience can be very rewarding if you enjoy the idea of helping others.  The atmosphere is typically that of a family and there are many people who truly do care to help those that are in need.  The organization is financially healthy and a clear vision directs the different divisions.
cons: The company is growing and as a result there are significant growing pains.  Sometimes it seems that some teams don't understand the organization vision and therefore appear disorganized and performing things that are unclear.  Since those teams don't communicate their rationale behind their direction it creates even more misunderstandings and battles between teams that are mostly unproductive.  In my opinion this behavior is a result of mid-level management battling with each other.

review_title: Great Company. Happy to be a part of it!
pros: The culture is great. For me the best I have encountered out of all places I worked for in FL.  Coworkers, direct managers and other managers for other areas are really professional, caring and friendly. The environment is really upbeat. Everybody helps each other. A lot of teamwork. Managers are really good to work with. Everyone is really welcoming.
cons: The only con is the PDO system. It is accrued so you get a certain amount of days but you have to take out holidays out of that pool of days you accrue so all in all you are really starting with 6 days of PDO (aka PTO in other companies) so you have 6 days to use for vacation and/or sick time. Not that great compared with the market here in Orlando. Also, other things can be improved but they are insignificant if you look at the big picture and the fact that all companies have some room for improvement in terms of their systems and/or procedures.

pros: Decent programs for those that need additional financial assistance due to health complications or unsuspecting hardships. Most of the regular staff that don't make a lot of money are probably the most grounded, humble and overlooked people within the establishment.
cons: Leadership is clueless. There are way too may Directors and power positions. With that comes constant conflict of policy vs. favoritism. Nothing is set in stone and there are too many contradictions and exceptions to the rules... if your liked. As long as you can communicate well with others, you are a great candidate for a Leadership position. Unfortunately, the organization as a whole does NOT exemplify their mission statement of "Extending the healing ministry of Christ". Everyone and everything is about the almighty dollar. Shame on the Leaders of this organization... it used to be a great place to work.

pros: The marketing department is a great place to work if you are starting out or if you have a family. The atmosphere is to work hard and earn your flexibility. You'll get to know many people in different departments while in this position. They give you a lot of ability to come up with your own plans and strategic ideas. If you work hard, you can achieve a lot. They are great at offering team building activities such as friday trail rides on bikes etc to help you get to know the rest of the marketing team. Lots of community involvement and partnerships. Plus, you're off at 2:30 on Fridays!
cons: There is a lot of top down political challenges. Things have to be done a certain way due to the legal team and gives less creativity for the marketing department. The hospitals are somewhat in competition with one another. This makes it hard to communicate with each other and ask for advice from other marketers at your sister hospitals.

pros: None to talk about it’s bad
cons: A lot of problems with the company

review_title: Adventist Health System is a great place to work
job_title: Applications Specialist in Altamonte Springs, FL
pros: Working at Adventist Health System (AHS) is a very positive workplace.  AHS hires high quality professionals who are respectful and driven for excellence.  I enjoy working here because we are committed to driving innovation in healthcare using some of the latest technology.  Our leadership is committed to the mission of extending the healing ministry of Christ and I believe they are leading us to growth and continued success.
cons: The dress code is very formal and you have to wear a tie 4 days out of the week.  I wish there was a gym or fitness center, but unfortunately there is not.  There is not yet a culture of open communication and the communication is very top down and not as collaborative as I would like.  The majority of communication is driven through email, when I think there are better communication tools that we could be using to have more open conversations.

pros:
AHS is doing exciting and important work. Great opportunity to learn and be part of the cutting edge health care field. 
May have early leave on Fridays depending on your department and if work is done. Also a chance to occasionally work from home (also depends on department).
cons: PDO is well below industry standard and they have expensive/high deductible health insurance. Federal holidays, forced modified holidays, sick days deducted from your PDO balance. New Hires start at 8% accrual. After forced modified holidays, deductions for federal holidays such as Christmas, etc. you are left with about 1 week!! These days have to be used for all vacations and sick days. This is not done at any other company that I know of.

review_title: In IT, they pay well and use advanced technology for a hospital
pros: I've been around healthcare IT for a long time and most hospitals are very backward technologically. HITECH is changing that, but FH recognized that earlier and invested in HIT heavily. They do pay well and seldom fire anyone. Layoffs are unheard of. Recently got "Best Hospital in Florida" from US News, "Most Wired", and rated as an excellent place to work by Gallup.
cons:
It is Seventh Day Adventist and that permeates the culture. If you are anti-religious you won't like the constant messages of "Healing ministry of Christ". That being said, I work with atheists, Jews, and Muslims who have been there many years. They talk religion a lot but nothing is forced on you. 

There's a dress code - khakis and polo shirts, no jeans or uncollared shirts. 

Though the tech is very good for a hospital, if you come from another industry you may find it a little backward.

pros:
The  organization is committed to their mission and they truly live their religion 
Wonderful working environment
The people are extremely friendly and very willing to help
Management really cares about their staff and this includes the personal growth and development.
The Information Security program is well funded and there is  a lot of executive support all the way up to the Board of Directors
Great progress is being made with the Information Security program.  The organization expects to start getting HiTrust certified in the next 20 months.
External auditors have confirmed the progress that has been made.
The organization is planning to double in size over the next 7 years so the demand for all skill sets will increase dramatically
It is a very exciting time to be part of this organization.
cons: The organization tends to move slowly and they still require you to wear a suit at work. Rather archaic :(

review_title: Longest place I've worked in my career
job_title: Senior Developer in Altamonte Springs, FL
pros:
The company cares about the morale of its workers and makes an effort to meet the requests of its employees.
This is one of the few companies that holds employee appreciation events.
The culture of being a “good neighbor” to the community is fostered throughout all levels in the company.
I enjoy the weekly and daily devotions that are encouraged in the company.
Most of the people that I’ve worked with, within and outside of my team are courteous, gracious and helpful.
These are some of the reasons why I've chosen to stay at the company for more than 8 years. Even when I've received other opportunities.
cons:
Every technical personnel must rotate being 'on-call'
I've not experienced a difference between executives of this faith-based organization and executives of secular organizations.

pros: Very nice to their employees. Family feel.
cons: I don't understand why AH  is allowed to hold people back for not being Seventh Day Adventist. Just because I am Catholic should not hinder my chances for growth. I know people who have been told outright they cannot interview for leadership roles because they are not Seventh Day Adventist. Why should it matter if I go to church on Sunday and not Saturday? That is discrimination. How is this legal? How have they been able to get away with something like this? There are some very qualified non SDA people there (including myself while I was still employed there) who should be growing and thriving. They give very low qualified SDA people very high level jobs just because of their religious beliefs. That is not right.

review_title: Most toxic work environment of my life, stay away
pros: Health care is pretty good, though you are forced to use AdventHealth providers
cons: Being in the non-medical side, any holidays or emergency days (hurricanes, for example) were taken out of your personal time off bank, and you didn’t have the option to do anything else (I.e. say you wanted to take no PTO and no pay, that was not an option). If you get pregnant, you have to take short term disability to cover it. Almost zero job growth potential. Had a co-worker far more skilled than me and with 10 years of service who barely made more than my starting pay. Toxic culture. I had a manager who was outright manipulative and only retained her position due to seniority and being an Adventist. A lot of politics that value the well-being of the company over employees. You will also not get very far if you are not an Adventist. Sincerely the most horrible work experience of my life, I got out as fast as I could and am so grateful I did.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Altamonte Springs, FL
pros:
Nice corporate facilities
Office closes at 3pm on Fridays
Offers health benefits for FT employees
cons:
-Compensation is WAY below the current market standard. ($10-15K difference)
-PTO does not make sense. You are required to use your own time for ALL holidays and even the modified days (day before/after the holiday)  They pay you absolutely NOTHING when the office is closed for holidays.
-They are allowing directors to move individuals into mgmt roles without them having any experience in leadership or even completing college. Its insulting when you have a manager with only a high school diploma.  
-No real room for growth unless you are part of the SDA community and/or a child or relative of a VP.

review_title: Worked Part Time In Education then preschool
pros: This is a hidden gem. Guest seem to like it here. It has really great exhibits. Our field trips always enjoy them selves in the exhibits. Staff is friendly but very cliquey. CEO actually talks to everyone which is nice and rare but....
cons: this has to be the worst paying place in Florida! Read all the other reviews..you do way too much work and you get paid less than theme parks..Its really sad! Hours are the worst as well! They hire like 30 educators and give them each like 10 hours a week..makes no sense! The scheduling they have for large groups is AWFUL! The reservations coordinator is ALWAYS on vacation...The only options of food is Subway or the vending machine..and if you are part time its not like you get a break anyhow! All the managers go out for lunch and they will stay gone for like an hour! The camp manager is the worst! She's so fake it comes off her flesh like if she's dreading fakeness!

pros: Christian atmosphere with lots of encouragement to get healthy physically and spiritually.  Diverse culture with other religions welcome also.  Most areas are not interested in political games, but rather good character and integrity.  Lots of room to grow your career in just about any professional field.
cons: They do not pay the best for their positions and sometimes that impacts quality of new employees coming on board.  They do not currently seem to train leadership roles with servant-based leadership ideals and tend to put "managers" or "supervisors" in place instead.  Not sure about other departments.

review_title: The company invests and supports their employees, through wellness initiatives and constant support.
pros: The mission is strong and the employees truly live the mission.  There are so many opportunities to be a part of the employee community.  The company takes time to get to know and support their employees.  The benefits package is fantastic.  The wellness program is more involved than I've experienced at any other company.  They have invested in making sure their employees are healthy and happy.
cons: There is a lot of nepotism among leadership.  The executive level seems to be detached from their employees.  There are unrealistic expectations on employees in regards to financial procedures.  We are expected to front money for many items instead of the hospital providing.  Many people in leadership positions behave in ways which are clearly against human resource policies with little/no consequences.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Altamonte Springs, FL
pros: As a very new employee here, my first experience with AHS has been extremely positive. I've meet many long-term people here (which gives me confidence that there is a high level of satisfaction to stay with the organization). Courtesy and actual kindness between the staff (and between management and staff) is a big deal to me at this point in my career, and I have had an excellent experience here so far in that regard. I am appropriately equipped to do my job, and I have been given to latitude to define my role and contributions.
cons: It would be nice to see some time flexibility in terms of working hours. The commute is at the peak of rush hour. Also, some remote time options would be attractive.

job_title: MIS Employee Non-leadership in Orlando, FL
pros: CEO Lars Houmann is a fantastic person.  FH spends a lot of time and effort promoting the mission to "Extend the healing ministry of Christ".  It is a faith based organization.  I have been fortunate that most of my career has been under fantastic leadership. review_title: Great place with room for growth and advancement
job_title: Senior Developer in Altamonte Springs, FL
pros:
- Work/life balance actually exists here
- Good benefits (medical/dental, 403(b) match and others)
- Active community involvement
- Generally relaxed and happy employees
- Leading-edge technologies and new ideas encouraged

Working for a faith-based organization where worship and prayer are not only allowed but encouraged and part of the daily operations definitely makes for happier employees and a more relaxed atmosphere as a result. Well, as relaxed as a corporate office can be. Of course it's all optional and you don't have to participate.

There's actually quite a bit of opportunity for career advancement laterally or vertically. There are some who started as interns and are now in the C-suite, others who started on helpdesk and are now directors. I also personally know some who have used their experience at AHS to advance their careers with other companies, moving upward into management roles. Another person I personally know moved up twice in one year.

The company does provide employees with activities outside of work, such as the company Christmas party and annual picnic (for IS employees.)

We do work with leading-edge technology and if you know of something that may work better or just want to try something new, you'll usually get the OK to go ahead. For example, one project we have the developer wanted to use Node.js and MySQL instead of ASP.NET or PHP and SQL Server. This project is now in production.

And it may seem cliché but I do feel that I have made true friends at AHS.
cons:
- Holidays are NOT paid
- Your vacation time is used for holidays and if you don't have enough you don't get paid
- Community involvement options are limited to "approved" activities
- Forced "modified holidays" burn more vacation time than you might expect

If you don't have enough time off accrued, your holidays are unpaid. Also they have the concept of a "modified holiday" which means you get two days off for a one-day holiday such as Christmas and New Year. Sounds great in theory but if you don't want to burn your time off on these modified holidays then you need special permission from upper management, which you might not be able to obtain.

Every year you are required to perform so many community involvement hours but they have to be from an approved list which doesn't include a lot. You can donate blood twice a year (at the blood drive at corporate), participate in the Corporate 5K or a few others. If you volunteer otherwise, such as as a little league coach, you don't get any credit toward your requirement even though you are giving back to your community with volunteer hours.

review_title: What A Contradiction to a Company that Calls Themselves Christians
job_title: Sales and Marketing Associate in Orlando, FL
pros: I loved my team, and I miss them every day.  That was mainly the only positive at this organization.
cons:
Let me begin by saying that my opinion reflects the marketing departments throughout Florida Hospital exclusively.  I have no idea what the company culture or compensation is like from a clinical perspective.  As far as I'm concerned, they are very different worlds.  

Marketing in general (between all of our campuses), was a very gossipy environment, full of "politics" and fear of stepping on one another's toes or having to be careful of what you said around certain campuses. I can totally come to expect that from any marketing firm as that is business to a certain degree, but it is rather discouraging when FL Hospital's mantra is to "Extend the Healing Ministry of Christ".  It was so not genuine for me when we would pray before meetings but then hear others talking negatively about their coworkers behind their back.  We were almost instructed from day one that Orlando Health was our enemy...we were expected to be excited when things didn't go well with their hospital and were encouraged not to support them in any way.  Looking back, I can't help but find this almost comical. At the end of the day, they are a HOSPITAL and they HELP PEOPLE.  Isn't that everyone's ultimate goal? Sorry, but Orlando Health has the leading level-one trauma center in the Greater Orlando area, and you better believe I will go there if I have the choice.  All in all, working in marketing for a Christian organization felt like a contradictory environment to me.  

Then there was the dress code that was very strict, but primarily only to females.  I mean, stuff as controlling as saying you can only have one earring per ear, couldn't wear more than one bracelet per wrist, and couldn't dress in a way that would serve as a "temptation to the men in the workplace”. I by no means consider myself a feminist by its true definition but COME ON.  I'm sorry, but if you don't feel as though the male employees you are hiring can keep it in their pants, then you have a MUCH bigger problem as an organization. I was with Florida Hospital from age 21-22, and as a young, attractive female, felt as though I was targeted simply because of that.  Someone on my team was tasked with the responsibility of telling me I was dressing inappropriately for work, and that there had been "complaints".  This particular employee who sat me down was someone I was close with and trusted, and I could tell she was simply being told to do this unwillingly.  I feel that as an adult that I was perfectly capable of being able to discern what is appropriate and what isn't for the workplace and was shocked and humiliated that she was having to tell me this.  Let's be clear: I primarily wear Anthropologie and Gap clothing, and don't even have cleavage.  Either way, I shouldn't have to justify anything for the sake of being a "temptation" to the creepy old middle-aged men who are rotting away behind their cubicle walls. 

Now, some of the more practical cons of Florida Hospital.  The health insurance is TERRIBLE.  WORST health insurance I have ever had, which is laughably ironic being I worked for a hospital.  They are so hung up on competing with Orlando Health that many providers are not available to us.  

Here’s a big kicker as far as terrible benefits go: you are forced to take PTO for holidays.  CHRISTIAN holidays at that.  I didn't get paid on Christmas Eve or Christmas because I didn't have enough PTO.  An absolute joke. 

My ultimate decision to quit came when my boss decided I wasn't valuable enough to deserve a graduate education.  Most employees at Florida Hospital are offered a tuition reimbursement program that assists in paying a certain amount per semester of continued education as long as you sign a contract to remain employed for (I believe) two years following the completion of the education.  Everyone else on my marketing team was eligible for this reimbursement, except for me, the only one who wanted to go back to school.  The reason being was that my employment was contracted differently than the others, a seemingly easy fix.  My boss' response to my desire to further my education?  "Don't go into student loan debt over it."  I was floored.  Keep in mind the dynamics of my team: a small group of kind, WONDERFUL women, the people I mention in the "pros" section that I miss every day, and a too-conservative, male boss that was clearly very old fashioned in how he felt men and women should serve.  Wow.  That was the exact moment I knew I wanted nothing to do with this organization.

Definitely costly initiatives that are in place just to keep our company family whole.

review_title: The Good, The Bad and the Ugly Truth About Advent Health
pros: The Good - Nurses typically support each other, they have too, otherwise AdventHealth would run them into the ground (that's it, nothing else good)
cons:
The Bad - (hmm, where to begin)
- horrible nurse staffing ratios, they scrape it to the bone and beyond
- propaganda (biased or misleading information) is a common technique used by AdventHealth, they are experts of illusion. Maybe that’s how they hire top execs, who has the best talent for presenting negative information to employees and convincing employees that they are actually doing them a favor. How about the creative raise in pay which when scrutinized closely, (shift differential, hourly rate, overtime, holiday pay, etc) and you look at the way it all fits together, you just took a cut in pay, benefits or both and you are supposed to smile and say thank you. Don't bother questioning their suspicious mathematics or reasoning, you already know the answer.
- you are an inconvenience to many employee support departments such as Human Resources, Payroll or Employee Health. They could care less if you have a problem (they try to make it so difficult to actually discuss a valid problem and even if you do manage that, they will either deny that any problem exists, refuse to acknowledge any responsibility for the problem, or you may never get an answer ... they just want you to go away and stop wasting their time, remember you are a nothing to them)
- AdventHealth executive management has no interest in you as a hard-working loyal employee (you are a machine to be used and disposed of when the time comes) They see the physical and emotional exhaustion associated with nursing as part of the job, they don’t want to hear about it, that would require them to show compassion towards the very employees that are integral to making billions for them. You might want do an internet search to see what top executives at AdventHealth make. Hint: Million(s). Times are tough though so the physical and emotional exhaustion nurses go though is only worth a few cents more and, by the way, were short on nurses right now, can you work some overtime because we’ve burnt through more nurses this month than we thought we would and we’re in a bind, you need to be a “team player” and we’ll toss you a few extra bucks (ouch) because we know you’ll grab at it in the hopes of having some semblance of enjoyable life, that is until we can hire some new machines .. oops sorry nurses … till we burn them out too.
- little to no chance for advancement, you can work for AdventHealth as a bedside nurse for years and never even get considered for a promotion regardless of whether you further your education, join committees or participate in things which benefit your unit and or hospital (remember upper management has no interest in you and it is extremely challenging, if not near impossible, to move away from the bedside, particularly if you are a good bedside nurse)
- hurricane time in Florida .. bring your own food, bring your own water, bring your own bedding, don't bring your kids though, even if you can't find someone to watch them, remember AdventHealth doesn’t care about you so why would they care about your kids.
- horrible health insurance (most patients have better health insurance), eg. you can buy certain prescription medication for 5 times less without using AdventHealth insurance at a non-AdventHealth pharmacy than you can buy it with AdventHealth insurance. To make it worse, they will call you and tell you "we would prefer you buy your routine medications from our AdventHealth mail order pharmacy". Imagine that, got to love those top AdventHealth execs, they are smooth, milking every dime they can out of their 80,000 plus employees, many of whom are nurses, for the very the products and services AdventHealth provides (so much for an employee discount)
 
The Ugly Truth - About AdventHealth - Founded by the Seventh-Day Adventist Church is this … AdventHealth IS ALL ABOUT MAKING MONEY, THEIR MONEY, AS MUCH IT AS THEY CAN POSSIBLE MAKE, ... PERIOD. They will invest in buying up hospitals, and building new ones, to expand their market share but will burnout nurses at phenomenal rates. They will talk about they care about nurses and "compassion burnout" (there’s that propaganda again) but AdventHealth executives have no compassion to begin with, particularly towards the very people that are caring for patients. Unfortunately, this attitude trickles down the management ladder. It is somewhat diffused and aerosolized by the time it reaches lower level management and most unit managers are more understanding and compassionate but you can still occasionally experience the same attitude due to the influences they are under from the upper rungs of the ladder.
As I am not a Seventh-Day Adventist therefore I cannot comment on their religious beliefs, nor do I feel it relevant to this review. I do however find it offensive the way they use religion to sell their propaganda of how they profess to be doing Christ's work when it is SOOOOOO obvious that all they care about is making money. Religious images are displayed everywhere with righteous and noble captions which obviously executive management doesn't read. Christ would never have treated people the way AdventHealth treats their employees. If you work as a nurse for AdventHealth (formerly Florida Hospital) you are treated as a nothing, and sacrilege (a violation or misuse of what is regarded as sacred) is common place as demonstrated by their behavior. Do an internet search on "Florida hospital lawsuit millions" and/or “adventhealth lawsuit millions” and learn more about this "NOT FOR PROFIT" hospital, their ethics, morals and Christian values.
 
If you want to work for a hospital, which only cares about making money and burns through nurses at an astounding pace then AdventHealth is for you.
 
Just so you also know, AdventHealth has their own nurse factory behind the hospital called AdventHealth University where they crank out new nurses to replace the ones that they burn out but their factory needs to crank up production, they’re burning through nurses faster than they can produce them. Think about it, why would a hospital be running ads for nurses if they have their own nurse factory. AdventHealth would likely tell you that it is because they are growing, which is partially true, but now you also know the rest of the story.
 
Good luck in your job hunting.
